title: How Block is becoming the most AI-native enterprise in the world | Dhanji R. Prasanna
key_insights: Moving from GM structure to functional organization was key to becoming more AI-native and tech-focused
AI tools are saving 20-25% of manual hours across all teams, with engineering teams reporting 8-10 hours saved per week
Non-technical teams using AI programming tools showed the most surprising productivity gains
Code quality has little correlation with product success - focus on solving real problems for users
Start small with everything rather than trying to 'boil the ocean' - successful products like Cash App and Goose began as small experiments
Leadership should use AI tools themselves daily to understand their capabilities and limitations before rolling out to teams
Conway's Law is powerful - you ship your org structure, so organizational design directly impacts outcomes
topics_discussed: AI manifesto written to Jack Dorsey
Organizational transformation from GM to functional structure
Goose AI agent development and capabilities
AI adoption across different skill levels
Future of engineering work with AI
memorable_quotes: A lot of engineers think that code quality is important to building a successful product. The two have nothing to do with each other.
All these LLMs are sitting idle overnight and on weekends, while humans aren't there. There's no need for that. They should be working all the time.
If you're not waking up in the morning feeling energized about what you're going to do that day in your professional life, then change something, quit if that's what it comes down to.
recommended_for: Engineers interested in AI productivity tools
summary: Block's CTO Dhanji Prasanna shares how the company became one of the most AI-native enterprises through organizational restructuring, building the open-source Goose AI agent, and achieving 20-25% productivity gains. The conversation covers practical AI implementation strategies, leadership lessons, and the counterintuitive insight that code quality doesn't correlate with product success.
